title: 110_s904
content: The Act titled "Veterans Small Business Opportunity Act of 2007" includes definitions. The Act titled "Veterans Small Business Opportunity Act of 2007" provides definitions for terms such as active duty, Administration, member of the Guard or Reserve, Secretary, service-disabled veteran, small business concern, small business concern owned and controlled by service-disabled veterans, small business concern owned and controlled by veterans, and veteran. The Act titled "Veterans Small Business Opportunity Act of 2007" provides relief from time limitations for veteran-owned small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to provide relief from time limitations for small businesses owned and controlled by veterans called to active duty after September 11, 2001. The Small Business Act is amended to provide relief from time limitations for small businesses owned and controlled by veterans who became service-disabled due to an injury or illness incurred during active duty after September 11, 2001. Upon submission of proper documentation, the time limitation extension shall be granted. The time limitation extension for small businesses owned and controlled by veterans who became service-disabled due to an injury or illness incurred during active duty after September 11, 2001, shall be equal to the period of time the veteran was on active duty. SEC. 4. STUDY ON OPTIONS FOR PROMOTING POSITIVE WORKING RELATIONS BETWEEN EMPLOYERS AND THEIR RESERVE COMPONENT EMPLOYEES. The Secretary is required to conduct a study on promoting positive working relations between employers and Reserve component employees, including improving notification time for active duty. A report must be submitted to Congress within 180 days, detailing measures taken to inform Guard or Reserve members of their obligations to employers. The Secretary is mandated to study ways to enhance working relations between Guard or Reserve members and their employers, including improving notification of active duty. The report must be submitted to the appropriate committees of Congress within 180 days. SEC. 5. LOANS. Guard and Reserve Loans under the Small Business Act are amended to increase the loan limit to $2,000,000 and allow loans up to $25,000 without collateral. The Administrator and the Secretary will provide information on small business programs for veterans, Guard, and Reserve members through a joint website and printed materials. The Administrator and the Secretary will conduct a study on increasing credit union utilization in small business programs for veterans, Guard, and Reserve members. They are also authorized to advertise and promote the program jointly with veterans' service organizations and lenders' trade associations. Within 6 months of enacting the Act, the Administrator and Secretary must submit a joint report to the Senate and House Small Business Committees on the study conducted regarding credit union utilization in small business programs for veterans, Guard, and Reserve members. SEC. 6. INCREASED FUNDING FOR THE OFFICE OF VETERANS BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT. Section 32 of the Small Business Act is amended to authorize increased appropriations for fiscal years 2008-2010. The Small Business Act is amended to establish an interagency task force to support small business concerns owned by service-disabled veterans and veterans in increasing capital and business opportunities. The Small Business Act is amended to establish an interagency task force chaired by the Administrator, with representatives from various government departments, to coordinate activities and develop proposals for increasing capital access for small businesses owned by service-disabled veterans and veterans. The Small Business Act is amended to support small business concerns owned and controlled by service-disabled veterans and veterans through loans, surety bonding, franchising, and increased access to Federal contracting. This includes using contract reservations, mentor-protege assistance, and matching opportunities to increase contracting opportunities for these small businesses and ensure the integrity of their certifications. The Small Business Act is amended to support small businesses owned and controlled by service-disabled veterans and veterans by reducing paperwork, improving access to business development opportunities, and making other enhancements related to veterans' business development by the Federal Government. The task force created will submit an annual report on its activities and proposals to relevant Senate and House committees. SEC. 8. VETERAN-OWNED BUSINESS DATABASE IMPROVEMENTS. The Administrator and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will review registration databases to ensure one-stop online registration for small businesses owned by service-disabled veterans and veterans. Criteria for the online registration will be established to maintain certification integrity. The registration requirements for small businesses owned by service-disabled veterans or veterans must comply with relevant laws. SEC. 9. BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT AND MENTOR-PROTEGE ASSISTANCE. Section 36 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a program for business development assistance for small businesses owned by service-disabled veterans. The Administrator, in cooperation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, may develop this program to expand contracting opportunities. The program aims to expand contracting opportunities for small businesses owned by service-disabled veterans, ensuring the success of procurement programs for other small businesses. The Administrator is required to submit a report within one year on the feasibility and terms of assistance for the program. Section 36 of the Small Business Act is amended to comply with Executive Order 13360, ensuring opportunities for service-disabled veteran-owned businesses.
